entry.title: Can we trust governments to tackle the climate emergency? | The Stream

media:group.media:title: Can we trust governments to tackle the climate emergency? | The Stream
media:group.media:description:
On Friday, the UN Secretary-General Antonio Guterres said if carbon emissions are not scaled back, the world will continue to be on a "catastrophic pathway" toward 2.7 degree Celsius heating. But is the threat of even more dangerous levels of global warming enough to finally convince governments into making the ambitious changes necessary to avoid a further climate catastrophe?
In the latest warning from the UN Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC), scientists say that unabated greenhouse gas emissions are pushing global temperatures and sea levels up faster than expected. An effective global response will require the world's richest countries to commit to significant reductions in burning fossil fuels.
The UN is using this week’s General Assembly meeting to build momentum on climate action ahead of November’s COP26 climate conference in Glasgow. Also central to the UN's agenda is "climate financing" for smaller countries that may be struggling to adapt to climate change.
But governments of the world's largest economies are all still failing to meet commitments made in 2015 during the landmark Paris climate change agreement.
In the first of three shows in partnership with the UN General Assembly, we'll discuss how governments are responding to climate change. Does the political will exist for a multilateral solution to the climate emergency?
Join the conversation: TWITTER: https://twitter.com/AJStream FACEBOOK: http://www.facebook.com/AJStream Subscribe to our channel http://bit.ly/AJSubscribe
#aljazeeraenglish #ajstream #climatechange

entry.title: Ecuador: Small town community protest to resist licensed mining

media:group.media:title: Ecuador: Small town community protest to resist licensed mining
media:group.media:description:
A community in the middle of the Andes mountains in Ecuador continues to resist the advance of mining companies. Residents from La Merced de Buenos Aires say they hope for a popular consultation to prohibit mining in their territory. However, Ecuador President Guillermo Lasso has created an action place to promote mining and is hoping to exploit more than 2.9 million hectares (7.2 million acres of land in the country.
Al Jazeera’s Teresa Bo reports.

entry.title: Several killed in shooting at Russian university

media:group.media:title: Several killed in shooting at Russian university
media:group.media:description:
Six people have been killed in a shooting in the Siberian city of Perm. A lone gunman was detained after the attack at the university campus. Local media identified him as an 18-year-old student. His motive remains unclear.
Al Jazeera’s Nadim Baba reports.

entry.title: What's the future for global cooperation at the UN? | Inside Story

media:group.media:title: What's the future for global cooperation at the UN? | Inside Story
media:group.media:description:
World leaders and diplomats are back in New York to attend the United Nations General Assembly this week. They have a lot to get through, including climate change, COVID-19, and the fallout from the Taliban’s return to power in Afghanistan. The UN Secretary General says growing mistrust between countries is making it difficult to tackle global crises. So is there a future for global cooperation?
Presenter: Imran Khan
Guests: Simbal Khan - Peace and security Consultant, UNDP Pakistan. Matthew Bryza - Former U.S Diplomat and Senior Fellow, Atlantic Council. Sanusha Naidu - Senior Research Fellow, Institute for Global Dialogue.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: Thousands evacuated after volcano erupts on Spain’s Canary Island

media:group.media:title: Thousands evacuated after volcano erupts on Spain’s Canary Island
media:group.media:description:
Thousands of people have been told to leave their homes, after a volcanic eruption on the Spanish Canary Islands. The eruption followed a week of increasing seismic activity on the island of La Palma. With a population of 85,000, La Palma is one of the eight volcanic islands in Spain’s Canary Islands archipelago off Africa’s western coast. At their nearest point, the islands are 100km (60 miles) from Morocco. The lava's slow advance has already consumed entire buildings and authorities are still unsure of the lava's future path.
Al Jazeera’s Andrew Simmons reports.

entry.title: ‘Hotel Rwanda’ hero given 25-year sentence in ‘terrorism’ case

media:group.media:title: ‘Hotel Rwanda’ hero given 25-year sentence in ‘terrorism’ case
media:group.media:description:
Paul Rusesabagina – a one-time hotel manager portrayed as a hero in a Hollywood film about the nation’s 1994 genocide – was found guilty of being part of a group responsible for “terrorist” attacks and sentenced to 25 years in prison by a Rwandan court. Rusesabagina boycotted Monday’s verdict after declaring he did not expect justice in a trial he called a “sham”.
Al Jazeera’s Malcolm Webb joins us live from the Rwandan capital Kigali for the latest updates.

entry.title: Afghanistan’s minefields: Bomb disposal teams call for more funding

media:group.media:title: Afghanistan’s minefields: Bomb disposal teams call for more funding
media:group.media:description:
Decades of war in Afghanistan have left large parts of the country littered with unexploded ordnance and landmines that have taken a devastating toll on civilians, mostly children playing and farmers working their fields. Since the Taliban took over the country, Afghanistan’s international reserves have been frozen, leaving all initiatives strapped for cash. Local bomb disposal teams cannot complete their work, leading to fears that more people will die or be badly injured.
Al Jazeera’s Charles Stratford reports from Maidan Wardak province, Afghanistan.
- Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish/ - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera/ - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/
#Afghanistan #AfghanistanLandmines #AfghanistanHumanitarianCrisis

entry.title: United Russia party claims victory after three days of elections

media:group.media:title: United Russia party claims victory after three days of elections
media:group.media:description:
United Russia general council secretary says the party will have 315 of the 450 parliamentary seats. Numerous allegations of voter fraud and ballot stuffing reported in Russia's Duma election. Voting in Russia's parliamentary elections held over three days to limit spread of COVID-19.
Amitry Babich is a political analyst in Rossiya Sevodnya. He joins us live from Moscow to discuss this.

entry.title: The Crown, Ted Lasso win top Emmy awards

media:group.media:title: The Crown, Ted Lasso win top Emmy awards
media:group.media:description:
It is one of the biggest nights in television, the Primetime Emmy Awards, television's answer to the Oscars. This year, on-demand streaming services won a series of top prizes for their shows, cementing their rise to prominence in the television industry.
Al Jazeera's Victoria Gatenby reports.

entry.title: Haitian migrants undeterred as US begins removal flights

media:group.media:title: Haitian migrants undeterred as US begins removal flights
media:group.media:description:
Hundreds of Haitians who had been hoping to find refuge in the US have been sent back home to Port-au-Prince. The US is operating up to eight flights a day to send the migrants camped at a Texas town on the border with Mexico. The remaining 12,000 Haitians say that their country’s political crisis and natural disasters have left their country uninhabitable. Al Jazeera's John Holman reports from Acunya on Mexico's border with the United States.
- Subscribe to our channel: http://aje.io/AJSubscribe - Follow us on Twitter: https://twitter.com/AJEnglish - Find us on Facebook: https://www.facebook.com/aljazeera - Check our website: https://www.aljazeera.com/

entry.title: China pumps $14bn in cash into market amid Evergrande crisis

media:group.media:title: China pumps $14bn in cash into market amid Evergrande crisis
media:group.media:description:
China's Evergrande Group - the world’s most indebted real estate developer - has offered to pay back some of its investors with some of its properties. The company has been struggling to raise funds to pay debts estimated at $300bn. If it fails it could affect China's economy - the world's second-largest - but China pumped more cash into its banking system on Friday to avert a liquidity squeeze. Al Jazeera's Laura Burdon-Manley reports.

entry.title: 'Hotel Rwanda' hero Paul Rusesabagina awaits sentencing

media:group.media:title: 'Hotel Rwanda' hero Paul Rusesabagina awaits sentencing
media:group.media:description:
The man whose story inspired the Hollywood film Hotel Rwanda will find out if he is going to spend 25 years in prison. Paul Rusesabagina is credited with saving hundreds of lives during the genocide in 1994. He has since become a vocal critic of President Paul Kagame and is now facing terrorism charges. Al Jazeera's Malcolm Webb reports from Kigali, Rwanda.

entry.title: UN General Assembly: World leaders meet in New York before summit

media:group.media:title: UN General Assembly: World leaders meet in New York before summit
media:group.media:description:
The United Nations and the United Kingdom are convening a high-level meeting on climate change. The goal is to build momentum before the COP-26 summit in Glasgow this November. Al Jazeera's diplomatic editor James Bays reports.

entry.title: Lava pours from Canary Islands’ volcano, villages evacuated

media:group.media:title: Lava pours from Canary Islands’ volcano, villages evacuated
media:group.media:description:
Thousands of people have been told to leave their homes after a volcanic eruption on the Spanish Canary Islands. It follows a week of increasing seismic activity on the island of La Palma, 500km (310 miles) off the coast of West Africa. Al Jazeera's Alexi O'Brien reports.
